Award.AwardTitle: Weaving Islands of Cloth: Gender, Textiles, and Trade Across the North Atlantic from the Viking Age to the Early Modern Period.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Textiles were fundamental elements of material culture in the Norse colonies of the North Atlantic, gaining such importance in Iceland that cloth was used as currency throughout the medieval period. Textiles were woven according to strict legal standards and guidelines that regulated the length of legal cloth as well as thread counts. Understanding the changes in textile production through time can help shed light on how people adapted their material culture to a changing cultural dynamic as well as changing climates. In addition, because cloth was produce by women and decisions about textiles resided in the household with women, this research helps us to understand not only how Norse society adapted its technology during a cooling climatic period by weaving thicker, warmer cloth, but also how such environmental change might impact basic social structures such as household decision making processes. This research can be a window into how social, cultural and economic systems will adapt to contemporary climate shifts and assist in preparing us for potential changes.

The project builds upon the PI?s former research taking advantage of the exceptionally well-preserved archaeological textile material to provide insights into the social contexts of textiles from the North Atlantic islands over a course 1000 years (ca. 800s-1800s AD). The overall aim is to gain a better understanding of the lives of women- frequently invisible in the archaeological record- and their role in developing trade and shaping the economies of the Norse societies. The designation of weaving as women's trade is rooted in the gendered cosmologies that prohibited men to enter weaving huts and engage in textile work in pre-Christian era Iceland. Ca. 1200 AD textiles emerge as currency commodity, showing consistent trend toward standardization, which continues through the 16th century, suggesting at least three centuries of co-existence between standardized fish (Cod, a key component of the Norse and world economy, including the first commodities market) and standardized cloth. Aware of the differences in the legacies of the approaches to weaving in Iceland and Greenland, the PI aspires to explore the variation between those, Faroes, and Norse Scottish Isles and asks what can be learned about expression of regional identities, Little Ice Age adaptations, and roles of women.


The PI will conduct on-site analyses of museum collections of materials from 6 Icelandic sites, 22 Greenlandic Norse sites, 1medieval Faroese site, and 21 Norse sites of Scotland; analysis includes extensive typologies, AMS dates, and dye identification. Part of the effort includes isotopic analysis that will attempt to trace movements of textiles and wool and possible trade networks across the region. This component is pitched as a pilot project that will assess the feasibility of using strontium and carbon isotopes on wool - a developing methodology that may help define the locale of the grasses consumed by sheep. Isotope analysis aims to connect the archeological record to the historical sources, which suggests that in early 1100s Icelandic textiles served as clothing material for the poor in England, Norway, and Germany.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Weaving Islands of Cloth carried out a comparative, 1000-year examination of textiles as evidence for women’s labor and roles in the Norse colonies of the North Atlantic in the 9th century AD and developed, over the following millennium, into the modern nations of Scotland, the Faroe Islands, Iceland, and Greenland. Through these analyses, it provided new insights into the ways these island nations developed, creating the foundations for international trade, developing national identities, and contributing to the survival of all but one of the Norse colonies in the North Atlantic.

 As objects made by hand that can be traded easily, textiles can be incredible sources of information on both the environmental hardships and cultural challenges that people faced in the past. In this grant, we used a portable X-Ray Fluorescence(pxrf) instrument to identify the elemental "fingerprints" of dyes or mordents in textiles, which allowed us to understand whether local or imported materials were used by North Atlantic women. But beyond that, we used XRF to trace the movement of cloth at local, regional, and long-distance scales, which represents a new and unique application of the technology. We found that textiles were traded and circulated in medieval Norse Greenland between settlements that were hundreds of miles apart, as well as between farms in the same regions. We found that textiles from farms close to Eirik the Red’s farm, the famous Viking who founded the Greenland’s colonies and whose son was the first European to explore the New World, wore woolen clothing that had high levels of uranium from soil contaminants that had been absorbed by sheep as they grazed. We are not yet certain whether this affected settlers in this district but it raises interesting questions about environmental health in the past that would not have been recognized without this work on textiles. One can also imagine that similar levels of uranium rich soils also permeated the houses they lived in. This in turn may be information of use to current populations who are farming and occupying the same farms in this general area.

 

 Fig.1 The use of the xrf Bruker Tracer III-SD, and readings from cloth.

 Contrasts between the ways that Icelandic and Greenlandic people made and used cloth were also extremely informative. Both colonies started with identical approaches to making and using textiles. However, in Iceland cloth became currency by the late 11th century, and remained important as currency until the 17th century. The quality of the cloth used for paying taxes, settling fines, or purchasing goods was legally regulated according to strict standardized criteria, as is the case with any currency. However, in Greenland no such use of textiles as currency existed as the colony was smaller and the conditions much harder. There, textiles were used for domestic purposes, were not exchanged as currency, and were not internationally traded. When climate cooled during the Little Ice Age, the Greenland Norse changed their farming strategies to incorporate more goat, a hardier species than sheep, adding their hair and other fibers from animals such as Arctic hare to their wool. Additionally, we determined that they created a new type of cloth adapted to the colder conditions and recycled old cloth into new garments. Dating one of the exceptionally well-preserved garments from the burial site of Herjolfsnes, showed that bits of cloth 100 years older than others were patched to create new garments and suggests both poverty and isolation in Greenland before its Norse colony disappeared.

 Looking farther to the west, I was able to examine an important set of textile objects from Arctic North America through the supplement to this grant. These have direct bearing on questions about the earliest European exploration of the Americas. Some of these had previously been used as evidence for a second Viking site on Baffin Island (Canada) and for Norse influence on American Arctic cultures. Pieces of spun yarn found on sites of the ancient Dorset culture paleo-Eskimos were thought by previous investigators to be non-indigenous and either Norse or Norse-inspired. However, my analysis of these fibers indicates that they were all made from the wool and fur of wild Arctic species, and date to the early and middle Dorset periods (AD 200-700), far too early to be Norse at all (10th-15th century). These artifacts instead represent important and previously under-recognized evidence of Native American cultural creativity and innovation in the Arctic regions. However, small numbers of woven textiles from two later sites in the Canadian Arctic do show evidence of early contact with ancestral Inuit of the Thule culture. One, from a Thule culture village high in the Canadian Arctic, does document contact through trading or raiding with the Greenlandic Norse. The others, from Baffin Island, provide rare evidence of contact between European explorers and early Inuit during the 16th century.
